deck: Imprint of New Leaf Publishing Group
description:
Specializing in reproductions of rare and unusual books from the 19th Century and earlier. The high quality reproductions serve as a historical education resource and are produced as they've found them.

The reproductions all reflect Christian Values and proclaim God as Creator.
name: Attic Books

deck: The informal name coined by Michael Drace Fountain, Marcel Losada, James Ninness and Joe Pezzula for their self-publishing collective. Created the Rue graphic novel and the In Sanity, AZ horror anthology as their first works.
description:
The informal name coined by Michael Drace Fountain, Marcel Losada, James Ninness and Joe Pezzula for their self-publishing collective. Each of the four men has a different background. Michael worked in theater for 10+ years. Marcel's specialty is ancient literature and he's a grammar god. James works his magic on short comic book stories. Joe is a film buff and creator.

Together they created the Rue graphic novel and the 'In Sanity, AZ' horror anthology as their first works. They've produced four comics (as of 2013), deliver a monthly podcast and are currently (2013) working on an unnamed prose project which will most likely be done at the end of 2013 and will then be self-published.
name: Quad Shot

deck: Self publishing for Rembrand Le Compte
description:
Beardfluff started out as an autobiographical comic when Rembrand Le Compte started his first real job. Since then it has evolved into a collection of humorist comics mixing the surreal with everyday life events. Some are in color and some in black and white. Updates are made at least once a week on Wednesday.

The author of all the comic strips, Rembrand Le Compte, made his comic counterpart to look a lot like himself. The only difference being that his counter part loses his temper 'slightly less often'. He works in Ghent, Belgium from the comforts of a room with a computer, drawing supplies and lots of tea.

He sells digital collections of his work on his own website.
name: Beardfluff Comics

description: Based in Cape Town, South Africa 'They Did This!' specialize in comic, illustration and design using the skills of several talented artists.
name: They Did This!

volumes.name: The Lil' Five and the Secret of the Black Cave

deck: Committed to producing intelligent, thought provoking and quality comics
description:
One Thursday back in 2009 writer Jeremy Whitley and illustrators Jason Strutz and Charlie Harper started Firetower Studios in the Southpoint Mall Food Court in Durham, North Carolina. They currently produce two comic series: 'The Order of Dagonet' and 'Princeless' in association with Action Lab Entertainment. They also produce five webcomics: Jeremy and Jason’s “Faerie Sisters”, Jeremy and Alicia’s “Hot Interracial Marriage”, Charlie’s “Crazy Normal”, Jeremy and Rich’s “Werewolf D.A.”, and Jeremy and Charlie’s “Ennui of the Dead”.

Publications (current as of dec 2013):

  • The Order of Dagonet, 6 issues
  • Princeless, 4 issues
name: Firetower Studios

volumes.name: The Many Hazards of Dimensional Hangouts

deck: Big Beard Comics is a DIY comic book company dedicated to publishing bad ass original comics
description:
Big Beard Comics strives to create new and original comic books that would not make it to press any other way. Marc 'Big Beard' Cheever started the company in 2011 and soon realized that his love for comic books was shared by many who were also trying to get their stories told. Marc Cheevers and Justin 'INVI' Vilonna are the foundation of the company, creating comics, recruiting writers and artists, handing out flyers and visiting every comic store from Miami Gardens to Palm Beach gardens. Self publishing is not easy but they're going the extra mile making sure they get their word out. Their main business focus's on the Miami area for now, but they hope to expand their business into the rest of Florida and dare I say the rest of the world.

Publications (up to dec 2013):

  • Camp Monster Lake (2012)
  • Paper Tentacles
  • The Goddless
  • ZippyCakes and SnotMuffin, 3 issues
name: Big Beard Comics

description:
Gary T. Becks, Jason Lenox and David Paul founded Ugli Studios in 2011. They focus on creator owned comics and it has become a showcase for several of the up and coming artists and creators. Ugli Studios funded a couple of their releases by using the kickstarter website.

Releases include:

Ugli Studios Present #1, The Art of Jason Lenox Vol. 1 (fully funded by kickstarter), The ends #1 and #2, The Courier and Painted Ladies of San Quentin (black and white edition) (fully funded by kickstarter).
name: UGLI Studios

description: Richard Comely started this company and produced two issues of Star Rider and the Peace Machine which both came out in 1982.
name: Star Rider Productions Ltd.

volumes.name: Star Rider and the Peace Machine

description:
The publisher Extrem Erfolgreich Entrerprises (translation: Extremely Successful Enterprises) (EEE) published 81 comic issues in 22 series. All published material was for adults only, most of them being horror comics. The company was owned by Bela B. who was perhaps best known for being the drummer in the punk rock band 'The Doctors'. He has a great affinity with anything to do with horror and even had a cameo in the Quentin Tarantino movie Inglorious Bastards.

He shut the company down in 2006 after stating in an interview that only producing about four titles a year wasn't enough to make him a real publisher. He'd decided to shut the company down after that.
name: Extrem Erfolgreich Enterprises

Superzelda: The Graphic Life of Zelda Fitzgerald
Kurt Cobain: When I Was An Alien
The Rising of the Shield Hero
The Rising of the Shield Hero

Kid Crazy and the Kilowatt King

description:
Cider Mill Press is a privately held publishing company in Kennebunkport, Maine. It specializes in well designed and uniquely formatted books with fresh and interesting content.

They have an imprint line called 'Applesauce Press' under which they publish their children's books.

Currently they are publishing a wide range of books. They are mostly known for their Peanuts range.
name: Cider Mill Press

description:
The company's owner Mikael Tegebjer (born as: Mikael Svensson) produced titles from 1982 - 1994.

  • Ballong (1994), 1 issue
  • Banala serier (1982), 5 issues
  • Comicaze (1986), 1 issue
  • Cult (1986), 1 issue
  • Lillen igen (1985), 1 issue
  • Lillen komplett (1985), 1 issue
  • Moch-out! (1986), 1 issue
  • Rolf Gohs (1990), 1 issue
  • Seriefloran (1985), 12 issues
  • Zombie (1985), 1 issue
name: Klöver comix

description:
Origin

In 1997 the unknown BVBooks published the first and only issue of 'Brinke of Destructioon'. The comic was in black and white. The cover was in full color and there is only one cover variant known to exist. BVBooks also printed a book cooked the H Files. The H Files was a spoof on the X-Files.
name: BVBooks

deck: Biggest comic and pop culture distributor in the world, publisher of Previews Magazine.
description:
Diamond Comic Distributors (DCD) was established in 1982 by Steve Geppi. The wholesale company specializes in non-returnable comic books, graphic novels and all related pop culture merchandise .

DCD is the largest distributor of entertainment product lines in the world and currently has three distribution centers worldwide, namely: Olive Branch MS, Plattsburgh NY and one in Cheshire, United Kingdom.

Their main focus is a magazine they bring out called Previews where their extensive stock and items available for pre-order are listed. In this magazine you'll find Comics & Graphic Novels, Magazines, Books, Trading Cards, Apparel (like T-shirst, hats and more), Collectibles & Novelties, Games and a wide variety of DVD's. Retailers can order from them directly trough their web-based services or via the order form found in Preview magazine.

Some might think the magazine is outdated with all the new possibilities that websites bring, but the Previews magazine is still in high demand from retailers and customers who can buy the magazine at their local store.

DCD is the Premiere Supplier of: Dark Horse Comics, DC Comics, Image Comics, Marvel Comics and Wizard Entertainment.

And they are the Exclusive Supplier of: Archie Comics, DC Direct, Diamond Select Toys and Gemstone Publishing.
name: Diamond Comic Distributors

deck: Gabriel Creations, Inc. is the publisher of BIOWARS: The Battle Rages Within digital comic book.
name: Gabriel Creations, Inc.

description:
Bookseller company E.P. Dutton was founded in Boston, Massachusetts in 1852 by Edward Payson Dutton.

Dutton expanded to New York City in 1864 where he began publishing religious books. In 1869 the company headquarters moved to New York City where they had their first bestseller, the two-volume The Life of Christ by Frederic W. Farrar, published in 1874. A deal was made with English publishing company J.M. Dent in 1906 to be the American distributor of the Everyman's Library series of classic literature reprints. In 1923 John Macrae was named president after the death of E.P. Dutton who had remained at the helm. John Macrae had started at the company as an office boy in 1885 and worked his way up the line.

The publishing and retail divisions were split into two separate businesses in 1928 with Macrae taking hold of the publishing side. Macrae would work for the company an amazing 59 years. The company was now known as E.P. Dutton and Company, Incorporated and under Macrae's leadership it flourished into one of the biggest independent publishers in the United States. Among their extensive list of writers were John Hunt, Cleveland Amory, Milton Glaser, Françoise Sagan, Lawrence Durrell, Luigi Pirandello, John Irving, Joyce Carol Oates, Peter Matthiessen, Gavin Maxwell, Gail Sheehy, Ruth Manning-Sanders, La Toya Jackson and Mickey Spillane.

Dutton Children's Books is one of the oldest children's book publishers in the United States. They are most known for their Winnie-the-Pooh range.

In 1986 the company was taken in by the Penguin Group and once again split into two. The imprints Dutton and Dutton Children's books now exist as imprints of the Penguin line with Dutton being a boutique line, publishing approximately 40 books per year. Half of them fiction and the other half non-fiction. About 25% of their releases hits the New York Times bestseller list each year. They had an excellent run in 2012 when four of the books they published hit the #1 spot on the New York Times bestsellers list: Believing the Lie by Elizabeth George, Stay Close by Harlan Coben, Winter of the World by Ken Follet and the headline-making No Easy Day: The Firsthand Account of the Mission that Killed Osama bin Laden by Mark Owen.

At the moment (2013) their company President and Publisher is Brian Tart, who started at the company in 1998 as Editor in Chief. He was named Publisher in 2005 and just a year later he was President.
name: E. P. Dutton

description:
From 1941 to 1951 the Anglo-American Publishing Company Limited (AAPC) produced 37 series with a total of 372 issues. The company started up after American comic books were barred from crossing into Canada because of the War Exchange Conservation Act passed in 1940.

To fill the need for Canadian kids to read American comics in what is later referred to as the Golden Age of comics the AAPC started producing Canadian reworks of American publishers comics like Fawcett Comic titles such as Captain Marvel and Joe Louis - Champion of Champions.

After the war the ban was lifted and the American comic producers could once again sell their own products in Canada, which eventually led to the downfall of the AAPC.
name: Anglo-American Publishing Company Limited

volumes.name: Dot and Dash and the Lucky Jingle Piggie

description:
Suhrkamp Verlag was founded in 1950 by Peter Suhrkamp who had also founded the S. Fischer Verlag in 1936. Suhrkamp was arrested by the Gestapo in 1944, but survived the concentration camp. When Suhrkamp started his own company he took a lot of writers from S. Fischer Verlag with him to his new start-up company. Among the first writers he produced work of were Rudolf Alexander Schröder, Hermann Kasack, T.S. Eliot, George Bernard Shaw and Bertolt Brecht.

Siegfried Unseld joined the company in 1952, becoming co-owner in 1957 and it's publisher after Suhrkamp died in 1959. He led Suhrkamp Verlag until he died in 2002. His widow Ulla Berkéwicz now leads the company which has 140 workers and a yearly turnover of about 40 million euros.

Suhrkamp Verlag, producer of fine European literature moved it's headquarters from Frankfurt to Berlin in 2010 and filed for bankruptcy in 2013 after a long battle for control of the company between Ulla Unseld-Berkéwicz and minority shareholder, Hans Barlach. The two battled in court for many years, costing the company a lot of money and substantial damage to it's image. Recently (in March 2013) Barlach was awarded a 2.2 million euro profit distribution following a court decision in December 2012 that Unseld-Berkéwicz and other Suhrkamp leadership had misused funds and should be fired from their respective positions with the Suhrkamp company, leaving Unseld-Berkéwicz ownership unaffected.

A new type of bankruptcy available under German law, called Schutzchirmverfahren (translation: protective shield process) was created to make it easier for viable businesses to restructure themselves. Businesses applying for Schutzchirmverfahren are given three months to restructure themselves, while still maintaining control of their business. The new law making this possible was passed in March 2012 and this is the first time a publishing house has taken the opportunity to use it. No one knows exactly what the overall effects will be, but the effects for Barlach seems clear. He's being disenfranchised and may also lose the 2,2 million euros that were awarded to him by the German courts.
name: Suhrkamp

story_arcs.name: The Return of the Green Knight

volumes.name: Mallow Man: The Sweet Taste of Justice

description:
Hamster Bomb Studio is a comic studio which currently (2013) works on two comics, 'R' and 'Dawn'.

The studio was started by Alex Healey (writer), while he was still in college, in a need for him to get his comic book stories out to the world after not hearing back from Image and Abstract comics. He works together with artist Kim Wallin (for 'R') and John McCoy (for 'Dawn').
name: Hamster Bomb Studios

deck: Expanding the world of the novel Fallen Heroes through transmedia storytelling
description: The company was started by Barry Nugent who wrote the self published book Fallen Heroes which became a bestselling hit in bookstores. Barry is working hard on the second book of the Fallen Heroes trilogy, which falls into the much larger Unseen Shadows Universe for which comics, books and audio cd's are made making his story the center of a much larger world.
name: Unseen Shadows

description: Gee Whiz! Entertainment was an Australian based studio based in Brisbane, Queensland. It started in 1996 in partnership by John Passfield and Steve Stamatiadis. Both men have an extensive background in comic books, having first been in business together in the studio called Interactive Binary Illusions that they started in 1993. In 1999 the studio formed a joint-venture with another company and became Krome Studios Pty Ltd.
name: Gee Whiz Entertainment

description:
QAM Comics currently runs two series of comics which can be read on-line on their website.

The first comic run is Template which is written by Quinton Miles, the art is done by Andres Quezada, colors by Nathan Lumm and lettering by MaGnUs. This comic series started in April 2013.

The second is Xeno Trip which is written by Quinton Miles, has art by Daniele Cosentino, colors by Giulia Priori and lettering by MaGnUs. This brand new series started it's first run in December 2013.
name: QAM Comics

deck: A comic imprint of Amazon founded in 2013.
description:
Jet City Comics was launched by online giant Amazon in 2013, and is also located in Seattle, Washington. Besides the Emerald City, Jet City is another nickname of Seattle.

Jet City first launched a mini-series of the online comic Wool, a comic adaption of the fantasy book series The Foreworld Saga, called Symposium, and another comic adaption, Meathouse Man, of George R. R. Martin's short story of the same name.
name: Jet City Comics

Published 7 issues (#3-9) of Tales of Jerry the Stoned Vampire (issues 1-2 were published by Karma Komix Production).

Their logo and that of Karma Komix Production are the same except for the name. It stands to reason that they were probably led by the same person(s). Though very little is known of them they did produce the Tales of Jerry the Vampire from 1984 - 1989.

description: Kasco Mills produced free giveaway comics to help spread the word about their animal food and health products. The two promotional issues are Kasco Komics #1 - Kasco Komics and Kasco Komics #2 - Kasco Komics.

deck: Producer of many popular shows including The Flintstones, Yogi Bear, The Jetsons, Super Friends, Scooby Doo and The Smurfs.
description:
Hanna-Barbera Productions, Inc. was an American animation studio that dominated American television animation for three decades in the mid-to-late 20th century. It was founded in 1957 by former Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer animation directors William Hanna and Joseph Barbera (creators of Tom and Jerry) and live-action director George Sidney in partnership with Screen Gems, the television arm of Columbia Pictures. Sold to Taft Broadcasting in late 1966, it spent two decades as its subsidiary.

Hanna-Barbera was known not only for its characters, but building upon and popularizing the concepts and uses of limited animation. Over 30 years, successful hit cartoons were produced, including The Flintstones, Yogi Bear, The Jetsons, Wacky Races, Scooby-Doo and The Smurfs. For their achievements, Hanna and Barbera together won seven Academy Awards, eight Emmy Awards, a Golden Globe Award and a star on theHollywood Walk of Fame.

Hanna-Barbera's fortunes declined in the mid-1980s when the profitability of Saturday morning cartoons was eclipsed by weekday afternoon syndication. In late 1991, the studio was purchased from Taft (by then named Great American Broadcasting) by Turner Broadcasting System (Ted Turner's company), who used much of its back catalog to program its new TV channel, Cartoon Network. After Turner purchased the company, Hanna and Barbera continued to serve as creative consultants and mentors.

Turner merged with Time Warner in 1996 and the studio became a subsidiary of Warner Bros. Animation, into which Hanna-Barbera was absorbed after Hanna died in 2001. Cartoon Network Studios continued the projects for the channel's output. Barbera went on to work for Warner Bros. Animation until his death in 2006.

As of 2016, the studio exists as an in-name-only unit used to market properties and productions associated with the Hanna-Barbera library, specifically its "classic" works. In 2005, the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences honored Hanna and Barbera with a bronze wall sculpture of themselves and their characters.
name: Hanna-Barbera

volumes.name: Hurry: Adventures of the Rabbitoid Knight
Mummator and the Conquerors of the Cosmos
Frankenstein and the Conquerors of the Cosmos

description:
Grand Design Digital is the digital publishing division of Grand Design Communications.

ABOUT GRAND DESIGN COMMUNICATIONS – Grand Design Communications LLC is a licensing agency representing comic books and graphic novels for worldwide print and electronic publishing rights. Their clients include Eureka Publishing, Wayne Vansant, John Bolton, Ann Nocenti, Heroic Publishing, Max Bunker Press, New Paradigm Studios, Roy Thomas, Jamal Igle, Gary Cohn, Doug Murray, and Russ Heath. Past clients include Top Shelf Productions, Oni Press, Dave Cockrum, Hyperwerks, and Alex Simmons. GDC also publishes in print and digital, and offers graphic novel packaging and consulting services. As one of the most experienced comics-focused licensing agencies, Grand Design Communications LLC has long worked to offer established and developing comic properties to content publishers worldwide.
name: Grand Design Digital

deck: World wide brand of ice cream
description:
The company started selling ice cream in 1922 in a factory in Acton, London (UK). In 1959 they doubled their maximum capacity by opening another factory in Gloucester (UK).

The company is now owned by Unilever and uses a worldwide known double heartlogo with different names for different countries (see picture).
name: Wall's Ice Cream

deck: Independent publisher from the United Kingdom
description:
Dogooder Comics is a new small-press publisher committed to putting out original, visionary and entertaining comics from the UK’s brightest creators.

Dungeon Fun was their first release look for more books in the near future.
name: Dogooder Comics
